title: Can I legally use a short quote from someone in a book? - Quora

response.answer_text: Technically this is a question for your publisher, who will do a clearance check on your book before they publish it making sure that you are not doing anything illegal. If you have a quote, they are going to take steps to make sure it is either a fair use or that you have permission. Or if you are self-publishing, work with an editor to make sure the above happens before you publish. But the short answer to a really complex issue is that: it depends. You told us nothing of the source of the quote. Some are usable, some aren’t. You told us nothing about how you are using it. Is this a use that falls under criticism, review, or parody? Is this an academic use where you are substantiating an assertion in your book? We know nothing about what sort of book you are writing: text book, novel, cookbook? A place where you would fail without permission is a use in fiction where you quote a line from a book or poem at the start of a chapter to set the tone. For that you need permission, because that is not fair use. But again, work with an editor—or better, a publisher—to resolve issues like this AFTER you have written the book. Writing a book is hard enough already, stop making problems for yourself during the creation process and just write the damn thing.

The previous answer is actually incorrect. This is a complicated issue best detailed by Jane Friedman in this post: A Writer's Guide to Permissions and Fair Use | Jane Friedman When you see those cool epitaphs in published books, know that the publishing house and author had to jump through a lot of hoops to get them there and usually pay money to license the material.
